blog.name: villanelleismyeviltwin
blog.title: Killing Eve is My Obsession
blog.description: Villaneve obsess with each other. I’m obsessed with them, especially Villanelle. She is my evil twin and I love her to the moon and back! Everything on this show is fucking genius! So, this blog is dedicated to anything related to Killing Eve, Jodie Comer, and Sandra Oh only — not multi-fandom. If you’re looking for Killing Eve stuff, just get on board. I make gifsets when I have free time. Visit My Site if you'd like. I do some shitty stuff there LOL!

tags: do you know how to dispose of a body?
summary: Okay, can we talk about Eve hurting herself on purpose for a sec? The thing in the first episode of season 1 I think when she...
question: Okay, can we talk about Eve hurting herself on purpose for a sec? The thing in the first episode of season 1 I think when she cut open her leg just to see what it would do made me think but then when she was repeatedly hurting herself with the pen unsettled me. As someone who has self-harmed before it shows some self-hatred in Eve that I don't think has been discussed before. Even if it is little things it's not healthy
answer:
Thank you bringing this up anon.

In season 1, that scene she cuts her leg just for curiosity indicates she has some subconscious dark bravery inside. It lets us know “OK, she has darkness and can hurt herself but she doesn’t do it out of self-hatred.”

But in 2x01, as an ex-self-harmed addict myself, I’m pretty sure Eve extremely has self-loath caused hugely by guilt in the scene she hurt herself with a pen. The thought of she might have killed someone and the subconscious dark bravery motivate her to do that. I think Eve not only has a silent nervous breakdown because of Villanelle only, but also her marriage. Deep down, she unconsciously represses her guilt towards Niko’s boredom that she has never mentioned a word about this to him despite of the fact that she tells him everything. And now, we can see that she’s not the same Eve to Niko anymore. She doesn’t tell him anything like before.

I came across someone’s good analysis about Eve’s attempt to please Niko as she had always done when her  dad was alive. I think it had been in her for so long until the stab happened. It ignites everything she represses and never thinks she can do - stabbing Villanelle + hurt herself. I’m pretty sure she will be darker than self-harm in this season. I even guess that she might unintentionally kill someone someday.

I’m sorry I’m not good at analysis and I’m not sure what I wrote makes sense to you or not. Sorry if it doesn’t, it’s just my two cents.

summary: So I know ur big on the theory about Villanelle kinda still mentally being a child and after that last episode I really agree...
question: So I know ur big on the theory about Villanelle kinda still mentally being a child and after that last episode I really agree with it because even her voice seemed like it had an almost childish lisp to it but I don't know if she was doing it on purpose for Gabrielle
answer: i caught that too. i think eve stabbing her kind of broke her. i think she really regressed after that happen, and she’s actively trying to avoid being hurt. she even gets mad when gabriel suggests it was fucked up or stupid. she’s trying to make it a positive because her feelings were so raw in that moment, and she feels taken advantage of, like eve saw her fucking bare soul and tore it apart. now, she’s pushing that hurt deep down and countering it with immaturity and humor, her only defense mechanism.

blog.name: morningmightcomebyaccident
blog.title: a convenient distraction
blog.description:
greywing @ lj
ctrlx/greywing @ AO3
Orphan Black fanfic
By following this blog, you agree to be bombarded by long text posts. Have a good day.

title: Killing Eve 2x01
body:
Unedited audio of my live watch, which means that it’s paced to the episode and thus a lot of dead air. (Which also doubles as a test of streaming and my mic. My laughter might blow out your ears, so beware.)

Bullet points if you don’t want to listen:

  • I wasn’t wowed but I wasn’t disappointed. Really loving Carolyn–and Fiona Shaw in this role–and I feel like the initial intrigue of the season will center around her: How much does she know? What is her angle in regards to keeping Eve in the game? What is her goal? Did she and Julia have an affair with one another and, if not, why not? I don’t necessarily feel eager for next week, but I look forward to seeing a plot ramp up. Season 1 was really paced kinda breakneck and I’m wondering if they’re going to try to match that pace or if this is gonna slow down.
  • Yellow titles for the first time? The show looks as slick as ever. Love the music still.
  • Loved small details of the episode: The blood on the rail, the domesticity of the Polastri household like we see Eve folding laundry, the crocks being just a little too small (lol), that the taxi cab driver is an immigrant to France, Oliver lol, how they’re giving Jodie more foreign language dialogue than she’s probably comfortable with?
  • Shout out to Sandra Oh, too, for being able to tap back into that mindset of panic and shock after a hiatus. That’s jumping back into a season going 100 mph. Also the way that Oh transitioned out of the fugue via getting pulled back into the thrill of the chase? Eve is not a substance abuser in the way the stranger interpreted her to be an addict, but she is addicted to true crime and chasing and unraveling those puzzles–she gazed into that abyss, the abyss gazed back and threatened to consume her, but her mind and her interests are simply wired to engage them. The puzzle is a distraction from one thing, but it’s also the drug that intoxicates Eve and reels her in further than she can recognize. I loved the coverage of Carolyn enjoying watching Eve getting lured back into the rabbit hole, that smile when Carolyn sees the gears start turning in Eve’s mind. I don’t know why Carolyn wants Eve at this point–what she wants Eve to do–but there’s something vicarious in the way that Carolyn feeds Eve bait to light her up.
  • I am frustrated that both Carolyn and Eve asked questions of one another that no one even remotely answered.
  • I do have some questions, like if Villanelle’s reaction to the stabbing–interpreting the stabbing as an act of love, was always in the cards with the writing of the finale of Season 1 or if that was a development that came with breaking Season 2 in the writers’ room? 
  • The episode kind of felt humdrum–because the pacing was so much slower than usual and kind of low energy because Villanelle is injured and Eve is in shock and trying to process what happened in Paris–but then the show threw that curve ball of Villanelle snapping Gabriel’s and I was right back in that thrill of the show of having been plunged into shock. I think it’s interesting, too, that Villanelle probably saw her actions as an act of kindness? It was what Gabriel said he wanted, it was more merciful in her POV to be dead than to live forever in that state (because it “would be shit”)–and thus that opens an interesting can of worms because while murder is murder, Villanelle’s motivations kinda makes us reevaluate her. Her solutions/thinking/rationale/conclusions are off-base in terms of what we’d view as the “norm” and the social contract, but that’s a different place for her to come from (as opposed to acting selfishly, as she does at every other point of this episode), and so that’s an interesting… start? Villanelle has a lot of self-awareness. Her dialogue is very bald and straightforward on this point. So I do wonder about this “mercy” kill. It’s not out of character; she killed promised to kill what’s-his-face, Eve’s boss, quickly. Like I guess I wonder if there’s any emotion in the action or what? I mean, you need only look at how Eve has reacted to stabbing Villanelle to how perfunctorily and casually Villanelle made the decision to end Gabriel’s life.
  • Similarly, when the woman at the bar started talking to Eve, I was like: Who does that? Maybe that didn’t strike others as strange, which means some of y’all are way kinder and compassionate than I am.
  • That said, I saw absolutely zero reason why Gabriel would have helped her out initially. I didn’t buy it. But I do find it interesting that the people whose kindness that Villanelle preys on this episode are men. 
  • I feel bad for Niko. I’ve always felt bad for Niko. His side of the story is legit and it’s hard watching him to try to navigate a marriage in which Eve is not gonna meet him halfway–and Carolyn serves as the model of BSing your spouse in order to pursue your real passion (and maybe duty, but really Carolyn and Eve and their ilk are compelled to go after these mysteries). In fact, it’s super interesting to think that Villanelle posed as a victim of domestic violence and yet… you know… Eve has committed domestic violence. She slapped Niko. Niko is so friggin’ understanding considering the degree of shit Eve has put him through. Ugh, I feel bad for him.
  • Not directly related to the show: Amazon’s captions are driving me crazy. They write contractions like “I’’m” and also their captioning of “[speaks Russian]” covers the in-show subtitles. GR.

Bullet points if you don’t want to listen:

  • Loved small details of the episode: The blood on the rail, the domesticity of the Polastri household like we see Eve folding laundry, the crocks being just a little too small (lol), that the taxi cab driver is an immigrant to France, Oliver lol, how they’re giving Jodie more foreign language dialogue than she’s probably comfortable with?
  • Shout out to Sandra Oh, too, for being able to tap back into that mindset of panic and shock after a hiatus. That’s jumping back into a season going 100 mph. Also the way that Oh transitioned out of the fugue via getting pulled back into the thrill of the chase? Eve is not a substance abuser in the way the stranger interpreted her to be an addict, but she is addicted to true crime and chasing and unraveling those puzzles–she gazed into that abyss, the abyss gazed back and threatened to consume her, but her mind and her interests are simply wired to engage them. The puzzle is a distraction from one thing, but it’s also the drug that intoxicates Eve and reels her in further than she can recognize. I loved the coverage of Carolyn enjoying watching Eve getting lured back into the rabbit hole, that smile when Carolyn sees the gears start turning in Eve’s mind. I don’t know why Carolyn wants Eve at this point–what she wants Eve to do–but there’s something vicarious in the way that Carolyn feeds Eve bait to light her up.
  • I am frustrated that both Carolyn and Eve asked questions of one another that no one even remotely answered.
  • I do have some questions, like if Villanelle’s reaction to the stabbing–interpreting the stabbing as an act of love, was always in the cards with the writing of the finale of Season 1 or if that was a development that came with breaking Season 2 in the writers’ room? 
  • The episode kind of felt humdrum–because the pacing was so much slower than usual and kind of low energy because Villanelle is injured and Eve is in shock and trying to process what happened in Paris–but then the show threw that curve ball of Villanelle snapping Gabriel’s and I was right back in that thrill of the show of having been plunged into shock. I think it’s interesting, too, that Villanelle probably saw her actions as an act of kindness? It was what Gabriel said he wanted, it was more merciful in her POV to be dead than to live forever in that state (because it “would be shit”)–and thus that opens an interesting can of worms because while murder is murder, Villanelle’s motivations kinda makes us reevaluate her. Her solutions/thinking/rationale/conclusions are off-base in terms of what we’d view as the “norm” and the social contract, but that’s a different place for her to come from (as opposed to acting selfishly, as she does at every other point of this episode), and so that’s an interesting… start? Villanelle has a lot of self-awareness. Her dialogue is very bald and straightforward on this point. So I do wonder about this “mercy” kill. It’s not out of character; she killed promised to kill what’s-his-face, Eve’s boss, quickly. Like I guess I wonder if there’s any emotion in the action or what? I mean, you need only look at how Eve has reacted to stabbing Villanelle to how perfunctorily and casually Villanelle made the decision to end Gabriel’s life.
  • Similarly, when the woman at the bar started talking to Eve, I was like: Who does that? Maybe that didn’t strike others as strange, which means some of y’all are way kinder and compassionate than I am.
  • That said, I saw absolutely zero reason why Gabriel would have helped her out initially. I didn’t buy it. But I do find it interesting that the people whose kindness that Villanelle preys on this episode are men. 
  • I feel bad for Niko. I’ve always felt bad for Niko. His side of the story is legit and it’s hard watching him to try to navigate a marriage in which Eve is not gonna meet him halfway–and Carolyn serves as the model of BSing your spouse in order to pursue your real passion (and maybe duty, but really Carolyn and Eve and their ilk are compelled to go after these mysteries). In fact, it’s super interesting to think that Villanelle posed as a victim of domestic violence and yet… you know… Eve has committed domestic violence. She slapped Niko. Niko is so friggin’ understanding considering the degree of shit Eve has put him through. Ugh, I feel bad for him.
  • Not directly related to the show: Amazon’s captions are driving me crazy. They write contractions like “I’’m” and also their captioning of “[speaks Russian]” covers the in-show subtitles. GR.
trail.content_abstract:
Unedited audio of my live watch, which means that it’s paced to the episode and thus a lot of dead air. (Which also doubles as a test of streaming and my mic. My laughter might blow out your ears, so beware.)

Bullet points if you don’t want to listen:

question: fair point but emerald only had a couple tv writing credits prior to taking over as well she was mostly known for acting, so who knows, it'll probably still be great :)
answer: i am hesitant to be optimistic because i have been burned before, but at least…. at least it’s a woman. i was confident in emerald bc she was phoebe approved. idk about this new chick. we’ll see. we will certainly see.

tags: I love when shows utilize their editing and music editing so well!!!!
summary: SHOUTOUT TO THIS AMAZING EDITING IN EPISODE 1 OF SEASON TWO. I love the creative ways they’re making it feel like V and Eve are...
body:
SHOUTOUT TO THIS AMAZING EDITING IN EPISODE 1 OF SEASON TWO. I love the creative ways they’re making it feel like V and Eve are still echoing one another but almost even more now, since season 1. Just with the way the shots flow into one another. 

AND! I’m not sure how many shows I’ve seen utilize a recap of last season with symbolism… it was cool that they edited two parallels screens and then when the characters united, so did the frames.

Lauren. 22. I'm really gay. Grad student (as of this fall) in astrophysics.

Main fandoms: Dark Matter (RIP), Killing Eve, Wynonna Earp, Legends of Tomorrow, Carmilla, Supergirl, The 100, Agent Carter, Orphan Black.

Main ships: Villaneve, Two (Portia) and Dr Shaw, Avalance, Wayhaught, Supercorp, Clexa, Sanvers (sort of maybe), Hollstein, Cophine, and Cartinelli.

summary: thoughts on the season 2 premiere: ahhhh my favs are backkk yess I don’t speak french so am I missing out on anything important?...
body:
thoughts on the season 2 premiere:

  • ahhhh my favs are backkk yess
  • I don’t speak french so am I missing out on anything important?
  • oh man that poor kid in the hospital, yikes villanelle chill for a sec
  • please less killing
  • ugh bodies and injuries freak me out I had to close my eyes a lot
  • eve just tell carolyn already
  • laughing way too hard about the windows thing
  • eve copes like how I do: just eating lots of candy and stressing

title: Killing Eve renewed for Season 3
body:
Killing Eve renewed for Season 3

Killing Eve has just been renewed for a third season, just ahead of the premiere of its second season. This follows the same pattern as last year’s almost instant renewal for a second season even as the first season just began. The third season will also be getting a new showrunner in Suzanne Heathcote (Fear the Walking Dead.)

Killing Everevolves around the suspenseful and unpredictable chase…

View On WordPress
